p: Other ethnobotanical surveys in neighboring valleys refer to the use of the infusion of P. mugo as digestive, and of its syrup as expectorant [ 3, 13, 15, 19]. From a pharmacological and phytochemical point of view, there are few studies in literature that can support this use and they all are based on characterization and evaluation of biological activity of the essential oil, often obtained from different plant matrices and from different geographic origins [ 135, 197, 198].
